Eating more high-quality carbs and fiber in midlife made a noticeable difference. The study suggests that what women eat in their 40s and 50s can impact their health decades later. Whole grains, fruits, vegetables, and legumes gave women a better shot at aging well. “Studies are starting to find an association between food choices in midlife and quality of life in later years. For the women in this study, eating well decades earlier paid off in a big way. They’re linked to lower risks of chronic diseases, sharper minds, and better physical health in old age. Women who upped their intake of high-quality carbs by 10% had a 31% better chance of aging well. It connected their midlife eating habits to their health in their 70s and 80s. But it’s not just about eating fewer carbs. High-quality carbs and dietary fiber aren’t just good for digestion. But once the researchers factored in fiber intake, that connection weakened. The more we can understand about healthy aging, the more science can help people live healthier for longer,” Korat said. Aging doesn’t have to mean decline, and it doesn’t have to mean slowing down.
